.  An old mining town, it is currently undergoing rebirth as a modest high-tech center and jumping-off point to a number of attractive areas in the mountains.  The small nearby towns of
, etc., are also covered in this article.
Grant County Airport is currently served by Great Lakes Airlines with non-stop service to Phoenix.  Road access is best from the southeast, via US 180 from
, and southwest, via NM 90 from I-10 near
.  NM 152 connects Silver City to I-25 near

to the east, and is a scenic and interesting drive, but one with some daunting hairpin curves that may challenge drivers of large, unwieldy vehicles.  Access from the north is sharply limited by the roadless

value: 538-5921.  Open Tu-F 9AM - 4:30PM, weekends 10AM - 4PM.  Free.  Memorabilia of Silver City's mining-town past.
content=Tickets to the Silver City Blues Festival, Pickamania! Festival, Folk Series, Youth Mural Arts Program, and performance series can be purchased here.
Plenty of Mexican food around town. All of them do one or two things really well but none are great across the menu.
content=Award winning local and foraged menu presented with modernist techniques. Best beer and wine selection in region.  2014 James Beard semi finalist for Best Chef - Southwest
content=Eclectic food with influences from around the world. The patio is beautifully landscaped. Wine and beer served.
content=Interesting is not quite the right word
, 1060 E. Rt. 180.  Indoor pool & hot tub, free high-speed wireless internet. Entire hotel is non-smoking. Usually one of the first to fill up.
content=Generic hotel-chain lodging, nothing special but comfortable. Newer building than the other nearby chain hotels. Includes free high-speed internet.
content=106 W. Broadway. Renovated historic hotel in downtown.
content=Charming vacation rentals in an historic adobe building have private native plants gardens.

content=Guesthouses, art gallery, and nature preserve on 265 Stress-Free acres, just far enough from Silver City to enjoy the incredible quiet and brilliant dark skies that make the Casitas special. Perfectly located to explore all the area's attractions. Full kitchens, seasonal fireplaces, continental breakfast, fantastic views of Gila Wilderness, free wifi. A Sunset Magazine "Top 10 Romantic Escape."

Silver City's mountain setting allows for a number of fine excursions to outdoor points of interest:

value: , south of town via NM 61.  Fee $5/day for day use; campground fees start at $8/night and range upward depending on access to hookups, etc.  A number of interesting short hikes are possible through weird terrain reminiscent of better-known
(another good, but long, excursion from Silver City).
http://www.nps.gov/gicl/ Gila Cliff Dwellings National Monument
north of town, a unit of the
.  Fee $3/day for individuals, $10/day for families; Park Pass applies.  Trails to archaeological sites are open for day use.  No lodging at the monument; plan to stay in Silver City.
is a large roadless area north of town, reachable via any number of trailheads in the area.  Good for day hiking and backpacking.
is a mining ghost town located six miles north of Silver City on State Road 15. It has been converted into a tourist attraction and features museums, restaurants, lodging, and art galleries.
